importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Col Michael Randrianirina was sworn in as head of state on this date, marking a pivotal moment in Madagascar's political transition following the protests.
The Gen Z movement publicly criticized the appointment of Herintsalama Rajaonarivelo as prime minister on this day, signaling a turning point in their engagement with the new government.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The protests began almost a month ago, creating a sustained period of youth-led political activism that pressured the government and ultimately led to a military intervention.

keyTakeAways: Gen Z Mada, a youth-led movement, protested against the appointment of Herintsalama Rajaonarivelo as prime minister, claiming the selection was non-transparent and lacked public consultation.
The movement argues that Rajaonarivelo’s ties to the previous government violate the goals of structural change they sought during the protests.
The protests initially began over water and power outages but evolved into broader demands for political reform and accountability.
Col Michael Randrianirina led a military coup and was sworn in as head of state on 17 October 2025, promising to honor the youth's demands for change.
Gen Z Mada continues to monitor the new administration and threatens sustained mobilization if the prime ministerial appointment remains unexplained or unchanged.
The youth-led movement asserts that their revolution will not be 'hijacked' and remains active in holding the new government accountable.

namedEntities.name: Gen Z Mada
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A youth-led political movement in Madagascar
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The movement is central to the article, as it led the protests that led to political upheaval and now challenges the legitimacy of the new prime minister's appointment.

namedEntities.name: Michael Randrianirina
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A military officer who led a coup and was sworn in as head of state
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is the new head of state who appointed Rajaonarivelo as PM, making him a key political figure in the current power shift.

namedEntities.name: Herintsalama Rajaonarivelo
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Businessman appointed as prime minister by Col Randrianirina
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The appointment of Rajaonarivelo is disputed by Gen Z Mada, who claim it is non-transparent and politically problematic due to past ties.

namedEntities.name: Andry Rajoelina
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former president of Madagascar who went into hiding during the protests
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His failure to address youth demands and subsequent disappearance contributed to the protests and the eventual military intervention.

namedEntities.name: CAPSAT
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: CAPSAT is referenced as the unit led by Col Randrianirina, which facilitated the military takeover that ended Rajoelina’s rule.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In Madagascar, a youth-led movement known as Gen Z Mada has protested against the appointment of businessman Herintsalama Rajaonarivelo as prime minister, claiming the decision was made without transparency or consultation and contradicts the movement’s goal of structural political change. The protests began over grievances such as frequent water and power outages and escalated into a nationwide demand for reform, culminating in the military takeover led by Col Michael Randrianirina, who was sworn in as head of state on 17 October 2025. While Randrianirina thanked the youth for their role in driving change, Gen Z Mada remains vigilant, asserting that their revolution will not be hijacked and threatening continued mobilization if the prime ministerial appointment is not explained or reversed.
title: Madagascar Gen Z protesters angry at choice of new PM Rajaonarivelo
